course_title: Southeast Asia in the Modern World

learning_outcomes.description: Understand the historical development of various forms of authoritarian rule in Southeast Asia.
Understand the social, economic, and cultural underpinnings of authoritarianism in Southeast Asia.
Understand the various interpretations of freedom and democracy in the context of Southeast Asian political traditions.
Understand the current authoritarian turn in Southeast Asian states.
Understand the historical role of competing external powers - e.g. European colonial states, China, the former Soviet Union, the US, and Japan - in influencing Southeast Asia.

assessments.task_description:
Tutorial Participation consists of:


(i) Weekly attendance and participation in the ten tutorials scheduled for the semester (10%)

Students are required to attend tutorials, having read the assigned tutorial readings, and actively participate in the discussion of issues raised in the lectures and tutorial readings.

Note: Tutorials start in Week 2.


(ii) Tutorial Presentation (10%)

Each student is required to give an oral presentation of no more than 6 minutes on a theme covered in the tutorial program. Students may choose to answer one or more of the tutorial questions, or focus on another issue that is directly related to the tutorial topic. The emphasis in the tutorial presentation is on not only understanding a particular topic but also on having the ability to communicate that understanding to an audience in an interesting and persuasive manner.


1. Presentation should be no longer than 6 minutes.

2. Presentation must address the topic for that week. 

3. Presentations should NOT BE READ. Speak to the class from your notes, rather than read from them.

4. Presentations should be done with enthusiasm! Be upbeat, but not casual.

5. Presentations should be intellectually stimulating and entertaining.

6. Focus on the main points. Don't go into too much detail. A presentation is not a research essay.

7. Presentations should be based on the assigned readings as well as other scholarly sources related to the topic.

8. Presentations should be well-structured: a clear introduction; two or three key points; and a clear conclusion.

9. A brief introduction and conclusion to your talk are important. Give them some thought.

10. Nervousness is normal! Use it to enhance your presentation.

11. Anyone can be a good public speaker. Like everything, all it needs is practice.


Note: Tutorials start in Week 2. The presentation schedule will be organized in Week 2's tutorial. Presentations will start in Week 3

assessments.assessment_title: Primary Source Analysis: DUE MONDAY 30th MARCH
assessments.task_description:
Length: 1000 words, +/- 10%.


Instructions: Primary sources are the raw material with which historians write their histories. This assignment is designed to introduce students to primary sources in Southeast Asian history, and to develop skills in analysing them critically.

On the Blackboard site for HIST2119 will be posted a series of extracts from various primary sources related to the theme of this course. Choose one of these extracts and explain its significance in the context of modern Southeast Asian history.

In your analysis you should cover the following issues:

(i) the year / period in which the source was composed;

(ii) the background of the person / people who produced the source;

(iii) the purpose for which the source was composed;

(iv) the political theory or philosophy, indigenous or Western, that is expressed in the source; and

(v) the broader significance of this source in terms of the historical context in which it was produced.

To assist in your analysis of this source you should refer to 2-3 works in the scholarly literature on the country and period of history in which the source appeared. An extensive bibliography is not required. Footnotes are not included in the word limit.


Referencing guide: https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/referencing/chicago17-notes-bibliography

Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. assessments.assessment_title: Essay, Podcast, or Documentary Movie: DUE MONDAY 25th MAY
assessments.task_description:
The major assignment in this course is to address one of the questions below in ONE of the following three forms: (i) Essay; (ii) Podcast; (iii) Documentary-style movie (using Apple's iMovie or Windows' Movie Maker, etc.).


The length requirement of each format is as follows:

1. Essay: 2500 words, +/- 10% (for referencing use Chicago style; footnotes are not included in word limit).

2. Podcast: 12-15 minutes

3. Movie: 12-15 minutes


QUESTIONS

1. Discuss the rise of one premodern Southeast Asian kingdom (e.g. Angkor, Pagan, Majapahit, Ayutthaya, Melaka, Dai Viet, etc.). What factors contributed to the rise of that kingdom, and how did it decline and fall?

2. How did European colonial rule impact upon traditional Southeast Asian political, economic, and social organisation? Answer with special reference to one country.

3. Discuss traditional patterns of gender relations in Southeast Asia. How did European colonial rule affect the status of women in Southeast Asia? (You may focus on one OR more countries).

4. Discuss the distinctive practice of slavery in Southeast Asia. How did it end?

5. Describe the nature of traditional relations between Southeast Asian kingdoms and imperial China. How did the coming of the European colonial powers impact upon that system?

6. How important was language to Indonesian nationalism? Or, Discuss language policy in any Southeast Asian country following independence.

7. What were the principal reasons for the collapse of European colonial rule in Southeast Asia after World War II?

8. Explain the rise of military regimes in many Southeast Asia countries following decolonization after World War II. (You may focus on one OR more countries).

9. Discuss the transformation of the arts and cultural life in one Southeast Asian country from the precolonial period, through the colonial period, to the post-independence era.

10. How did Southeast Asian governments attempt to modernize sports and physical education in the post-independence period? (You may focus on one OR more countries).

11. Discuss the rise of the women's movement in one Southeast Asian country in the late colonial and early independence period.

12. Why did Marxism appeal to so many Southeast Asians in the mid-twentieth century? (You may focus on one OR more countries).

13. Discuss the influence of the Maoist theory of the “semi-feudal, semi-colonial” society in Southeast Asia.

14. What factors were behind Vietnam's invasion and occupation of Cambodia from late 1978 until 1989?

15. How have Southeast Asian governments dealt with indigenous peoples since independence? You may focus on one OR more countries.

16. Illustrate and discuss the influence of socialism on the arts and cultural and intellectual life of one Southeast Asian country during the Cold War period.

17. What were the reasons for the outbreak of ethnic separatist movements in so many parts of Southeast Asia following independence? Choose ONE from the following: Aceh, Indonesia; Patani, southern Thailand; southern Philippines; West Papua, Indonesia; Sabah, Malaysia; or one of the ethnic armed organisations in Myanmar.

18. How have post-independence governments in mainland Southeast Asia managed the Buddhist religion, and how have Buddhist organisations or movements responded? Answer with reference to one country.

19. Explain the problem of integrating the ethnic Chinese in modern Southeast Asian nations following independence. Answer with special reference to one country.

20. Account for the rise of 'modernist Islam' in Indonesia from the 1800s to 1949.

21. Why has Myanmar been unable to achieve the degree of national unity by comparison with other Southeast Asian countries?

22. How has modernization since the colonial period impacted on gay, lesbian, or transgender identities in Southeast Asia? You may focus on one OR more countries.

23. What are the reasons for the Islamic revival in contemporary Southeast Asia? Answer with reference to one of the following: Indonesia,  Malaysia, Brunei, southern Thailand or southern Philippines.

24. Discuss the role of the Catholic Church in the EDSA 'revolution' that ousted President Marcos of the Philippines in 1986.

25. Discuss the differences in the way that Singapore and Malaysia have managed the issue of multiracialism in their respective societies.

26. How have political and economic modernization affected the status of women in Southeast Asia since independence to the present? You may focus on one OR more countries.

27. How does the history of sexuality in Southeast Asia differ from the history of sexuality in the West?

28. What are the reasons for the popularity of 'boys' love' dramas in Southeast Asia in recent years? Discuss in the context of the history of sexuality in Southeast Asia.

29. Discuss the relationship between China and Southeast Asia during the Cold War. You may focus on one OR more countries.

30. What are the historical reasons for the current civil war in Myanmar?


Research Tip: Focus your research on books, book chapters, and journal articles in History, not other disciplines or the mass media. Try to consult works listed in the weekly reading lists, as well as the recommended texts listed in Section 7: Learning Resources.


Submission:

1. Do not give your essay a new title. Simply state the essay question from the list above.

2. Footnotes are not included in the word count.

3. The word-count can be 10% over or under the word limit.

4. For video documentaries, submit the file through EchoVideo. For details see:

https://elearning.uq.edu.au/student-guides-original/echovideo-original/submit-video-assignment-echovideo-original

5. For podcasts and documentaries, make sure you also submit a Bibliography through Turnitin.


Referencing guide: https://guides.library.uq.edu.au/referencing/chicago17-notes-bibliography


Podcast Tips:

1. Focus on good engagement with the audience

2. Good research

3. Good structure

4. Clear voice & audio: don't speak too fast, and try not to read

5. Answer the assignment question

* NOTE: Since this is a History course, not a media production course, if you choose to do a podcast or video documentary the technical quality will not be a major criterion of assessment.

Week 2, LECTURE: Southeast Asia before Colonial Rule

This week's lecture presents an overview of Southeast Asia prior to the arrival of the colonial powers. It surveys the various kingdoms of the region, large and small, as well as the major religions and civilizational traditions: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Islam, Christianity, and the local popular religions. It discusses traditional social structures, premodern political ideas, and the great ethnic diversity of the region, one of Southeast Asia's defining characteristics.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3, LECTURE: The Making of the Colonial States and Decline of the Aristocratic Order

In this week's lecture we will examine the rise of European imperialism in Southeast Asia, focussing on the nineteenth century. The lecture will explain how the Dutch, British, French, Portuguese, and Spanish (and the Americans after 1898), overcame the traditional Southeast Asian kingdoms and established new, more modern colonial states. It will look at how European colonial rule brought changes to Southeast Asian economies, societies, and cultures. The lecture will also show how, ironically, colonial rule gave rise to a new Southeast Asian middle class which would become the main factor in the rise of Southeast Asian anti-colonial nationalism.

LECTURE: The Making of the Colonial States and Decline of the Aristocratic Order


TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

How was Southeast Asia colonized by the Western colonial powers? What effect did Western colonization have on Southeast Asian societies? How did the Western colonial states that formed in the late nineteenth century differ from the former Southeast Asian kingdoms? What did Furnivall mean by a "plural society" in colonial Southeast Asia? What happened to the traditional Southeast Asian rulers (e.g. kings, "emperors", sultans, rajas, the aristocracy and nobility) under European colonial rule? What were Ho Chi Minh's criticisms of French colonial rule in Vietnam? How did communist and nationalist critiques of colonial rule differ?

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4, LECTURE: Nationalism, World War II, the Japanese Invasion, and the Collapse of Colonial Rule

This lecture gives an overview of the great changes in Southeast Asia in the middle of the twentieth century which led to the sudden end of European colonial rule. It describes the rise of anti-colonial nationalist and communist movements in Southeast Asia in the 1920s and 1930s and the resulting colonial suppression of these movements; Japan's invasion of Southeast Asia in December 1941 following its attack on Pearl Harbour and its rapid defeat of the European colonial states; Japan's own defeat in August 1945 and the subsequent process - violent in some cases, negotiated in others - by which Southeast Asians gained their national independence in the period between 1945 and 1957.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: LECTURE: Southeast Asia in the Cold War I: Communism and the Indochina Wars

This week's lecture focusses on Southeast Asia's tumultuous history during the Cold War. It considers the reasons for the rise of communist movements after the end of the Second World War and the unstable period following Southeast Asian independence. It looks at the influence of Cold War superpowers in Southeast Asia at this time: the United States, the Soviet Union, and the newly-established People's Republic of China, and how Southeast Asia became a major battleground of the Cold War. The lecture also explains the complex history of the three Indochina Wars which devastated much of mainland Southeast Asia, including the 'Vietnam War'.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6, LECTURE: Southeast Asia in the Cold War II: Anti-Communism and Military Ascendancy

This week's lecture looks at the phenomenon of anti-communism in Southeast Asia between the 1940s and 1970s, in response to the rise of communist parties and insurgencies. It explains the failure of early attempts to create democratic systems in Southeast Asia following independence, and the rise of military dictatorships. The lecture gives particular attention to the Indonesian military's suppression of the Indonesian Communist Party in 1965-66, when perhaps half a million suspected communists were killed. The lecture shows how, in many cases, the political regimes that came to power in Southeast Asia during this time remain in power today.

Week 7, LECTURE: Historiography, Methodology, and Theory in Southeast Asian History

This lecture considers the ways that historians, local and international, have attempted to understand Southeast Asian history. It begins by examining indigenous historical sources such as inscriptions and royal chronicles. It discusses the rise of colonial historiography and modern historical methodologies in the second half of the nineteenth century; how Southeast Asia's independence led to a demand for 'autonomous history' free from colonial perspectives; the rise of 'Area Studies' in the United States in the context of the Cold War; the impact of nationalism and Marxism on history writing; and the struggles that Southeast Asian historians face in challenging official historical narratives pushed by authoritarian states.

Can we call these works 'history'? What are the main features of colonial historiography? What was Van Leur's criticism of colonial historiography? What did Smail mean by 'autonomous history'? Discuss the origins of 'Area Studies'. What is its method? How does it differ from colonial historiography? Discuss the influence of nationalism and Marxism on Southeast Asian historiography. How has Western theory impacted upon Southeast Asian history writing? Does social science theory derived from Western historical experience distort the Southeast Asian historical reality?

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8, LECTURE: Building Nation-States and the Issue of Ethnic Diversity

This lecture considers the challenges postcolonial Southeast Asian states have faced in building unified nation-states out of ethnically highly diverse populations. The lectures surveys the ethnic diversity of each state, their complex pre-colonial histories, and then describes how different states have gone about trying to create national unity in the post-independence period. The lecture also looks at the reasons for the rise of ethno-nationalist separatist movements in Myanmar, the southern Philippines, southern Thailand, and Indonesia.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8, TUTORIAL: Building Nation-States and the Issue of Ethnic Diversity

LECTURE: Building Nation-States and the Issue of Ethnic Diversity


TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

What did Anderson mean by describing nations as 'imagined communities'? What is ethno-nationalism? Why has it been such a problem for so many Southeast Asian nation-states in the period following independence? What did Clifford Geertz mean by the terms "integrative revolution" and "primordial sentiments"? Were ethnic separatist movements in Aceh, West Papua, East Timor, southern Thailand, southern Philippines, or Myanmar justified? Discuss the political ideology of the ethnic separatists in the post-independence era. How have Southeast Asian states attempted to integrate ethnic minorities? How successful have they been?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9, LECTURE: The Ethnic Chinese and Southeast Asia's Capitalist Transformation

Southeast Asia has the world's largest concentration of people of ethnic Chinese ancestry outside of China - about 35 million people. This lecture examines their long history in Southeast Asia. It gives particular attention to their importance to the Southeast Asian economies, dating from the pre-colonial period, through European colonial rule, and into the independence period. It considers the complex question of Chinese identity in Southeast Asia, their experience of discrimination, and the role that the largely ethnic Chinese commercial sector has played in Southeast Asia's economic transformation over the last 60 years. It also considers the relationship between the Southeast Asian Chinese and the People's Republic of China in an era when China has re-emerged as a great power.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9, TUTORIAL: The Ethnic Chinese and Southeast Asia's Capitalist Transformation

LECTURE: The Ethnic Chinese and Southeast Asia's Capitalist Transformation


TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

Why did King Vajiravudh (r. 1910-25) refer to the ethnic Chinese as "the Jews of the East"? Describe the position of the ethnic Chinese in the colonial societies of Southeast Asia. How did the rise of Chinese nationalism in the early twentieth century affect the position of the Southeast Asian Chinese? How did independence in Southeast Asia and the victory of the communists in China in 1949 change the position of the Southeast Asian Chinese? What role did the ethnic Chinese play in Southeast Asia's economic transformation since the 1960s? Discuss the relationship between the ethnic Chinese and Southeast Asian political regimes. Discuss the different degrees of social integration of the ethnic Chinese in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. How has the relationship between the Southeast Asian Chinese and the People's Republic of China changed since Chin's 'Reform and Opening Up' period to the present? 


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10, LECTURE: Gender Relations in Southeast Asian History and the Impact of Modernization

This lecture considers the comparatively high status of women in Southeast Asian history. It looks at their historically prominent role in local trade and commerce, and the significance of widespread social practices of matrilocal and bilateral kinship, uxorilocal residence, ease of divorce, and the right to inheritance. The lecture also considers the impact of colonial rule, national independence movements, the rise of the military, and economic transformation on the status of women. It gives particular attention to the emergence of women's movements across Southeast Asia in the twentieth century.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10, TUTORIAL: Gender Relations in Southeast Asian History and the Impact of Modernization

LECTURE: Gender Relations in Southeast Asian History and the Impact of Modernization


TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

Describe the social and economic status of women in early modern Southeast Asian states. How did it differ from East Asian, South Asian and European societies in the early modern period? How influential were the various religions in defining gender status? How did European colonization affect gender relations in Southeast Asia? How has the rise of new institutions such as bureaucracies, political parties, the military, the mass education system, etc. impacted on the status of women in Southeast Asia? How did socialists view the role of women? How has rapid economic development since the 1960s changed relations between men and women? Discuss the social position of gay and lesbian men and women and transgender people in Southeast Asia, in both precolonial and contemporary Southeast Asian societies.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11, LECTURE: Islam in Southeast Asia: History, Modernity, and Democratization

This lecture looks at the history of Islam in Southeast Asia from the precolonial period through to the present. It discusses the tension in Southeast Asian Muslim societies since the nineteenth century between 'modernist' and 'traditionalist' interpretations of Islam. It considers the impact of colonial role on Muslim society and the role of Islam in anti-colonial movements in Southeast Asia. It looks at the rise of Islamic political movements following independence and the suppression of these movements in Indonesia by the military dictatorship. Lastly, it considers the Islamic 'revival' among Southeast Asian Muslims since the 1980s as a result of economic growth and democratization.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11, TUTORIAL: Islam in Southeast Asia: History, Modernity, and Democratization

LECTURE: Islam in Southeast Asia: History, Modernity, and Democratization


TUTORIAL QUESTIONS

Does Islam in Southeast Asia have a distinctive character? Discuss the historical tensions between "traditionalist" and "modernist" Islam in Muslim societies in Southeast Asia in the twentieth century. Discuss the relationship between Islam and nationalism in the late-colonial and post-independence periods. How did Indonesia's New Order military regime deal with Islamist political movements? According to Hefner, what are the reasons for the "Islamic revival" in the Muslim-majority regions of Southeast Asia? How is it related to democratization? How can we explain the "conservative turn" in Southeast Asian Islam over the last three - four decades? How dependent are political and religious trends among Southeast Asia’s Muslims on events in the Middle East? How does Reid explain the rise of "puritan Islam" in modern Southeast Asia? Is he right?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12, LECTURE: The Military and Monarchy Strike Back: Thailand's Conservative Turn

This lecture considers the place of the monarchy and military in Thailand's modern history. It considers the following questions: what were the reasons for the overthrow of Siam's absolute monarchy in 1932? How did the People's Party view the monarchy? How did the royalist conservative, Prince Dhani Nivat, justify Thailand's monarchy in the post-1932 era? What were the reasons for the restoration of the Thai monarchy during the Cold War? What is the relationship between the monarchy and the Thai military? How has Buddhism been used to justify the political dominance of the Thai monarchy? What effect has the passing of King Bhumibol (r. 1946-2016) had on the Thai monarchy? How democratic is the Thai middle class?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13, LECTURE: China's Relations with Southeast Asia: Then and Now

This lecture discusses the relationship between Southeast Asian states and China dating from the pre-colonial period to the present. It discusses the so-called “Tributary System” and how it came to an end with the arrival of the European colonial powers in the nineteenth century. It looks at the resumption of relations between newly-independent Southeast Asian nations and the People's Republic of China after 1949, after a hiatus in official relations of almost a century. It assesses the increasing influence of China on Southeast Asian economies, politics, and foreign relations since the beginning of China's "Reform and Opening Up" period at the end of the 1970s. Lastly, it considers how US-China rivalry is affecting Southeast Asian countries, whether US hegemony in Southeast Asia in decline, and what this might mean for Australia.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
